newsitem.title: USA: Reality Interactive sees slower sales.
newsitem.headline: Reality Interactive sees slower sales.

text.p: Reality Interactive Inc said Thursday it expects revenues in 1996 to be in the $500,000 to $800,000 range, slower than the company had previously expected.
Reality chief financial officer Wes Winnekins said the company's expected revenues for the year had previously been pegged at $2 million.
The company said it has sufficient capital to continue with its current business plan.
Reality Interactive said the slower growth is a result of unexpected problems in setting up a direct sales force, and longer-than-expected sales cycles in businesses.

"Sales growth for 1996 has developed slower than we initially expected," Paul Wendorff, chief executive, said in a statement. "While this is disappointing to us, the company is performing well and the reaction to our products from existing and potential customers has been favorable."
CFO Winnekins said the company believes its basic sales strategy is correct, but he said it is too early to make projections for 1997.
The company began shipping this month its QS-9000 product, a CD-ROM series to help companies comply with quality standards of the major U.S. automakers.

"At this point in time it's probably too early to assess opportunities for '97," Winnekins said in a telephone interview, adding that QS-900 is considered one of the company's most important products.
Reality Interactive provides multi-media educational and training products to industrial companies.
